gloss: Connective: sumti afterthought or

meaning.exp: Logical connective: sumti afterthought or. Connects two sumti, such that the containing bridi is true if and only if it is true for at least one of the connected sumti.
meaning.note: Supplanted with {{ja}} in JACU.

example.lojban: .i xu mi klama lo mu'a ceizda {{.a}} lo mu'a pacraistu
example.english: Do I go to, say, heaven {{or}} hell?
example.author: Andy Weir

meaning.exp: Letteral for a. When used alone, refers to the most recent sumti starting with {{a}}.

example.lojban: .i ro da sutra fa'a {{la .alis.}} ca lo nu {{.a bu}} tolcanci
example.english: They all made a rush at {{Alice}} the moment {{she}} (= Alice) appeared.
example.author: Lewis Carroll

meaning.exp: Equivalent to {{.i pau}}. Starts a sentence that is by default a question.
meaning.note: Adopting ajbo prerequires adopting JACU. A sentence started with {{.a}} always contains a question marker ({{xu}}, {{ma}}, {{mo}} etc.)

example.lojban: {{.a xu}} do pu zi mo'u gunka tu'a lo do jibri
example.english: Did you just finished your job{{?}}
example.speaker: la srasu

example.lojban: {{.anai}} la loglan cu jbobau xu .i na go'i ni'i loka lujvo {{.a xu}} ku'i la loglan cu lojbo bangu
example.english: Are Loglan Lojban{{?}} It's not because of the lujvo [structure]. But is Loglan some kind of Lojban-ic language{{?}}
example.speaker: la melmi
example.note: The first sentence seems to be a question where the speaker is expecting a negative answer, but it's hard to say for sure because there are no other instences of {{.anai}} in similar usage.

meaning.exp: Starts a response to a question.

example.lojban:
— .i nancaji li xo
— {{.anai}} reze
example.english:
— How old are you (in years)?
— Twenty-seven.
example.speaker: la nonselcme, la srasu
example.note: The former sentence is compatible with CLL Lojban. The latter is in ajbo.

meaning.exp: Starts a rhetorical question.
meaning.note: This meaning is only attested once, making it a hapax. This usage is listed separately because this usage is mentioned (but not used) by other speakers.

example.lojban: {{.anai}} la catra cu catra xu zo'o
example.english: Does "Killer" kill{{? /j}}
example.note: This is the only instance of {{.a nai}} being used as a rhetorical question starter.
example.speaker: .kúblizel.

gloss: Attitudinal: intention — indicision/hesitation — refusal

meaning.exp: Attitudinal: express intent / purpose / design.

example.lojban: .i {{.ai}} mi ba snada ro se troci
example.english: I{{'ll}} succeed in everything I try.
example.author: Djemynai

meaning.exp: Attitudinal: express indecision / hesitation / vacillation / wavering.

example.lojban: ― .i pu zi co'i mo'u tinzga 100 zo'e .ibo ca surla .i {{.aicu'i}} tinzga lo velvi'u 400mei
example.english: ― Just finished listening to the first 100 and am now taking a break. {{Unsure if}} I'll listen to the remaining 400.
example.speaker: la lalxu

meaning.exp: Attitudinal: express rejection / refusal.
meaning.note: BPFK proposed changing it to "express unintention / accidentiality", but I didn't find usage of that.

example.lojban: .i go pu'o zei ganlo se morji gi ne'i la'e di'u milxe bacru za'a sei {{.ai nai}} tolmo'i
example.english: The unclosed memories, I hear whispers inside them that {{we never want to}} forget.
example.author: Youmi Kimura

gloss: Attitudinal: hope — despair

meaning.exp: Attitudinal: express hope / longing.

example.lojban: .i a'o ro da zabna
example.english: {{I hope}} everything is good.
example.author: la .cogas.

meaning.exp: Attitudinal: express despair / hopelessness / dread / fear.

example.lojban: .i le trene pu zi co'a cliva se ka'a lo tcadu poi darno {{.a'o nai}}
example.english: The train's just started to leave for the faraway city, {{oh no...}}
example.author: inabakumori

gloss: Attitudinal: interest — disinterest/indifference — repulsion

meaning.exp: Attitudinal: express interest / curiosity / concern / preoccupation.

example.lojban: .i {{.a'u sai}} .i ti lo nu mi sipna cu fanmo
example.english: {{Cool,}} this is the end of my sleep.
example.author: Djemynai

meaning.exp: Attitudinal: express disinterest / uninterest / unconcern / apathy / detachment / indifference.

example.lojban: {{.a'ucu'i}} .i ka'u mi'o na ba se fatri lo do'anai bongu .oi
example.english: {{Whatever.}} Now he won't even share the bones with us anyway...
example.author: Kenji Miyazawa

meaning.exp: Attitudinal: express repulsion / aversion / disgust / distaste / repugnance.

example.lojban: {{.a'u nai}} bu'o pilno lo do voksa
example.english: I {{don't want to}} use your voice anymore!
example.author: ryo

gloss: Emphasize next word

meaning.exp: Forethought emphasis indicator: Indicates that next word is especially emphasized or emphatic.
meaning.note: For grammatical purposes, {{ba'e}} marks the following word but does not change its nature. (The construct behaves just as the marked word by itself.) Multiple BAhE cmavo may be used in succession, and they combine to mark the next non-BAhE word.

example.lojban: .i ja'o mi bilga lo nu jmina finti {{ba'e so}} lo tricu
example.english: So I have to create {{nine}} more trees to add.
example.author: Worldbuilding Notes

example.lojban: .e'e ju'o ca le {{ba'e ca}} jeftu mi roldei tcidu ro se ciska be ro le mi jbope'o
example.english: {{This}} week, I definitely can read every day what all my Lojban friends have written!
example.speaker: latkerlo

gloss: language — to use (a language) — to be expressed with a language

meaning.exp: x_1 is a/the language/dialect used by x_2 to express/communicate x_3 (si'o/du'u, not quote).
meaning.note: For "(of a text) to be written in a language", both x_2 and x_3 are attested, though using x_3 is more common. See quotes.

example.lojban: .i pe'i cizra milxe fa lo nu krici lo du'u lo jugbau cu {{bangu}} le ceizda
example.english: I think it's a little strange to believe that Chinese {{is the language of}} Heaven.
example.speaker: la nalvai

example.lojban: .i ku'i mu'a la'a cu'i so'o da {{co'a se bangu}}
example.english: But, for example, there might be some {{emerging speakers [of the language]}}.
example.author: M. Paul Lewis and Gary F. Simons

example.lojban: .i le dei pagbu cu ro roi {{se bangu la .gliban}}.
example.english: This page is always {{in English}}.
example.note: Example of "(of a text) to be written in a language" expressed with x_2 of {{bangu}}.
example.author: Robin Lee Powell

example.lojban: ni'o da ze'u krici lo du'u lo tai selse'analka'e cukta cu {{te bangu}} fi lo prutce ja darno
example.english: For a long time it was believed that those impenetrable books {{were in}} ancient or distant {{languages}}.
example.note: Example of "(of a text) to be written in a language" expressed with x_3 of {{bangu}}.
example.author: Jorge Luis Borges

example.lojban: .i mi jinvi lo du'u lo me zoi gy jbo.wikipedia.org gy cu bilga co {{te bangu fi lo jbobau}}
example.english: I think stuffs in jbo.wikipedia.org should {{be in Lojban}}.
example.note: Example of "(of a text) to be written in a language" expressed with x_3 of {{bangu}}.
example.speaker: la srasu

gloss: Preposition (tense): retrospective

meaning.exp: Retrospective/perfect: signifies that the event has already ended; already.

example.lojban: .i lo jitro be lo te lanme {{ba'o}} cliva lo ra cmana
example.english: The shepherd of the flock {{has already}} left his hill.
example.author: la solpa'i

meaning.exp: in the aftermath of ...; since ...

example.lojban: ni'o {{ba'o}} le krixa ke cladu savru cu co'a klaku fa pi ro le drata prenu
example.english: {{After}} the deafeningly noisy screaming, everyone else started to cry.
example.author: Jin

meaning.exp: is already ended when ...

gloss: Grouping: short scope link, strong binding

meaning.exp: Short scope link. Used in various grammatical constructions and acts as a high precedence link, overriding usual left-grouping rules. Chains linked with {{bo}} are grouped to the right. Specific usages are explained below.
Joins tanru units, binding them together closely.

example.lojban: ni'o ze mo'o fenki tcati {{bo}} kansi'u
example.english: VII. The mad tea{{-}}party
example.note: The {{bo}} directly corresponds to the hyphen in the English text. Without the {{bo}} the tanru will group as {{[fenki tcati] kansi'u}}, which roughly translates to "the mad-tea party".
example.author: Lewis Carroll

meaning.exp: Override the default left-grouping in chained connectives. Constituents connected by connectives with {{bo}} are grouped first. Chains linked with {{bo}} are grouped to the right.

example.lojban: .i ku'i mi pu ku tcidu ba'e so'u pagbu be le to'e censa se ciska gi'e ba bo ga'orgau le cukta {{gi'e bo}} co'a bevri
example.english: Yet I had read only the least fragment of that blasphemous rune before closing the book and bringing it away.
example.note: The English sentence is grouped as "I had read... before [closing the book and bringing it away]". If the underlined {{bo}} wasn't there, it'll group as "I had [read... before closing the book] and bringing it away". This example also shows the right-grouping rule with chained {{bo}}: The {{gi'e ba bo}} in the example has a lower priority because it is to the left of the underlined {{gi'e bo}}.
example.author: H. P. Lovecraft

meaning.context: Between a NAhE and a sumti
meaning.exp: Binds NAhE and the sumti together.
meaning.note: Not required in later grammars such as camxes beta or zantufa.

example.lojban: .i mi ka'e binxo lo makcu prenu noi se cinri no {{na'e bo}} lo namcu
example.english: I may become like the grown-ups who are interested in anything nothing {{other than}} figures.
example.author: Antoine de Saint-Exupéry

meaning.exp: Forms a sentence link along with {{.i}} and the BAI modal. The resulting sentence link ({{.i BAI bo}}) tags the latter bridi as a whole by the BAI modal, and incorporates it to the former (main) bridi. {{BRIDI<sub>1</sub> .i BAI bo BRIDI<sub>2</sub>}} has a similar meaning to {{BRIDI<sub>1</sub> BAI lo su'u BRIDI<sub>2</sub>}} or {{lo su'u BRIDI<sub>2</sub> cu SELBRI lo su'u BRIDI<sub>1</sub>}} (where {{BAI}} is the modal for {{SELBRI}}), but {{.i BAI bo}} also asserts that both the linked bridi are true.

example.lojban: ni'o lo ka jinga nalka'e cu nalvai {{.i mu'i bo}} mi klama be tu mutce bo djica
example.english: It doesn't matter that I can't win, {{because}} I really want to go there.
example.note: The second {{bo}} in this example is of another usage (that inside a tanru).
example.author: Ibuki Tsubasa

meaning.exp: Forms a sentence link along with {{.i}} and the tense. The resulting sentence link ({{.i TENSE bo}}) tags the latter bridi as a whole by the opposite of the tense, and incorporates it to the former (main) bridi. {{BRIDI1 .i TENSE bo BRIDI2}} has a similar meaning to {{BRIDI2 TENSE lo su'u BRIDI1}}, but {{.i TENSE bo}} also asserts that both the linked bridi are true.
meaning.note: The implication of the relationship between connected sentences is the opposite for modals and tenses. The reason is likely historical, as said in Lojban for Beginners (p. 110): "The very astute reader will have noted that ‘afterwards’ should have been {{.i pu bo}}; the analogy with {{ba ku}} won out, though."

example.lojban: .e'u mi'o klama lo korbi {{.i ba bo}} mi do jungau lo lisri be mi
example.english: Let us get to the shore, {{and then}} I'll let you know my story.
example.author: Lewis Carroll

meaning.context: After a connective and a BAI modal
meaning.exp: Binds the connective and the model so that the model signifies the relation between the connected elements. {{.i je BAI bo}} are similar in meaning to {{.i BAI bo}}, and the meanings of other connectives can inferred analogously.
meaning.note: This usage is not unique to {{bo}}. Other grouping words like {{ke}} can also do this, but only those with {{bo}} are attested.

example.lojban: .i ca ro dunra lo clika co'a dunja {{je ja'e bo}} sligu
example.english: Every winter the moss freezes {{and becomes}} solid {{as a result}}.
example.author: Ryan Cross on Science

meaning.context: After a connective and a tense
meaning.exp: Binds the connective and the tense so that the tense signifies the time relation between the connected elements. {{.i je TENSE bo}} are similar in meaning to {{.i TENSE bo}}, and the meanings of other connectives can inferred analogously.
meaning.note: This usage is not unique to {{bo}}. Other grouping words like {{ke}} can also do this, but only those with {{bo}} are attested.

example.lojban: .i loi sorska cinta ko fi ko'a cu se punji {{.i je ba bo}} loi xekri tabno ko'a gacri
example.english: Paint it with colorful pigments, {{and soon enough}} it'll be covered in black charcoal.
example.author: Noise and Bells

meaning.exp: Forms a sentence link along with {{.i}}. The resulting sentence link separates bridi, but doesn't reset bridi level. Multiple bridi separated with {{.i bo}} shares the same prenex.
meaning.note: The above explanation is taken from roljbogu'e chatlog, under said explanation {{.i bo}} is analogous to {{.i je}}. In actual usage, however, {{.i bo}} often resets bridi level, making {{.i ji'a}} a closer analogue.

gloss: to learn, learner — to be learned, facts learned — subject of learning — source of learning — learning method

meaning.exp: x_1 learns x_2 (du'u) about subject x_3 from source x_4 (obj./event) by method x_5 (event/process).

example.lojban: .i mi {{cilre lo du'u ta'i ma kau zgipli lo flani kei}} mu'i lonu zdile
example.english: I'm {{learning how to play a flute}} for fun.
example.speaker: la ziren

example.lojban: .i mi ra'a {{cilre}} so'i da fo la lunbe ku noi .uinai cando do'e le jbogu'e ca
example.english: Related, I {{learned}} so much from Lunbe, who is now inactive in Lojbanistan :(
example.speaker: la janbe

example.lojban: .i mu'i ku so'i da pilno {{lo laldo ve cilre}} lo ka {{cilre fi lo catni lojbo}}
example.english: Because of it, many used {{old textbooks}} to {{learn the official Lojban}}.
example.author: la uakci

example.lojban: .i se ni'i bo ji'a ka'e {{cilre fu lo nu finti lo daskycizda'u cmene}}
example.english: Which means (entails) that [you] can {{learn by making Pokémon names}}.
example.speaker: la nonselcme

gloss: interesting event — to find interesting, to be interested in

meaning.exp: x_1 (abstraction) interests/is interesting to x_2; x_2 is interested in x_1.

example.lojban:
— .i xu do viska lo cnino trene
— .i go'i lo pixra be lo 777moi klesi trene .i ri na {{jai cinri}} mi
example.english:
— Did you see the new train?
— Yep, saw the picture of the Class 777. It didn't {{interest}} me.
example.speaker: latkerlo, la samflir

example.lojban: xu nai lo zekri poi .i'y gasnu ke'a cu {{cinri}} do
example.english: Doesn't the crime it ( = the word ie'o) caused {{interest}} you?
example.speaker: la lunbe
example.note: {{.i'y}} is a proposed cmavo equivalent to {{.i bu}}. Note that this example doesn't need {{jai}} because the x_1 of {{zekri}} is already an event.

example.lojban: .i lo nu citka cu cizra {{cinri}} sy.
example.english: The (act of) eating is strangely {{interesting}} to her ( = Susan).
example.author: Robin Lee Powell

example.lojban: .i mi ka'e binxo lo makcu prenu noi {{se cinri}} no na'e bo lo namcu
example.english: I may become like the grown-ups who are {{interested in}} anything nothing other than figures.
example.author: Antoine de Saint-Exupéry

gloss: to eat, to consume — to be eaten, food

meaning.exp: x_1 eats/ingests/consumes (transitive verb) x_2.

example.lojban: mi ba {{citka}} ma
example.english: What will I {{eat}}?
example.author: la lalxu

example.lojban: {{lo se citka ku}} mo
example.english: What happened to {{the stuff I was going to eat}}?
example.author: la lalxu

gloss: strange, weird — to find ... strange

meaning.exp: x_1 is strange/weird/deviant/bizarre/odd to x_2 in property x_3 (ka).

example.lojban: .i ku'i ro da {{cizra}} ca lo cabdei
example.english: But everything {{is strange}} today.
example.author: Lewis Carroll

example.lojban: .i a'o {{na cizra}} do fa tu'a ti
example.english: I hope (something about) this {{is not strange}} to you.
example.author: la solpa'i

example.lojban: .i la gregor cu {{se cizra}} lo vrici sance be lo nu citka
example.english: Gregor {{found}} the various sounds of eating {{strange}}.
example.author: Franz Kafka

gloss: to leave — place where x<sub>1</sub> leaves from — route of leaving

meaning.exp: x_1 leaves/goes away/departs/parts/separates from x_2 via route x_3.

example.lojban: .i .e'a ko mi {{cliva}}
example.english: Go ahead and {{leave}} me
example.author: Jonathan Coulton

example.lojban: .i ri'a tu'a lo ckule cidja mi binxo co bilma lo za'i ru'i {{se cliva lo ciblu lo kanla}}
example.english: Because of the school's food, I became sick, with {{blood}} continuously {{goes out through my eyes}}.
example.author: la blutolpinxe

example.lojban: ni'o xu lo prenu co vajni cu ge'i ca ranji lo nu kansa ku gi ve'u sepli do gi'e {{pu co'a cliva fi lo drata se litru}}
example.english: As for the people important [to you], do they continue to accompany you? Or are they now distant and separated from you, {{having departed via their own paths}}?
example.author: doriko

gloss: name, title — to be called as ..., to be named — to name, to call ... as ...

meaning.exp: x_1 (quoted word(s)) is a/the name/title/tag of x_2 to/used-by namer/name-user x_3 (person).

example.lojban: .i ma {{cmene}} do poi ke'a na slabu mi
example.english: What {{is}} your {{name}}, unfamiliar one?
example.author: 40mP

example.lojban: ni'o lo jmive poi ka'e prami cu ca ca'o {{se cmene}} fi lo remna fa zo remna
example.english: A living thing that can love is now {{being called}} "human" by mankind.
example.author: niki

example.lojban: .i ki'u ma lo cmalu ninmu cu {{te cmene}} dy lu te makfa li'u
example.english: Why did the little woman {{call}} her (Dorothy) "a sorceress"?
example.author: L. Frank Baum

gloss: novelty, unfamiliar — to be unfamiliar with ...

meaning.exp: x_1 is new/unfamiliar/novel to observer x_2 in feature x_3 (ka) by standard x_4; x_1 is a novelty.
meaning.note: I only found usages of x<sub>1</sub> and x<sub>2</sub> places.
meaning.noshownote: I found one usage of the x_3 place, but sadly the sentence has bracketing issues and I couldn't make sense of the sentence.

example.lojban: .i zgadi fa lo nu cusku fi do fe lo du'u lo xrani mi {{na cnino}}
example.english: I really should tell you that the world's dangers {{are nothing new}} to me.
example.author: Noise and Bells (la janbe)

gloss: Preposition (tense): initiative

meaning.exp: Initiative: signifies that the event starts.

example.lojban: .i mi {{co'a}} na kakne lo nu jitro
example.english: I {{start to}} be unable to control.
example.author: Fyren

meaning.exp: at the starting point of ...
starts when ...; since ...; from ...

example.lojban: .i xy. to'e lazni gunka {{co'a lo cerni}} co'u lo nicte gi'e na djuno lo du'u lo si'o gleki cu mo kau
example.english: He worked hard {{from morning}} till night and did not know what joy was.
example.author: L. Frank Baum

gloss: Preposition (tense): cessative

meaning.exp: Cessative: signifies that the event ends. The event is not neccesarily completed.

example.lojban: .i ko {{co'u}} tolckire gi'e prami mi
example.english: {{Stop being}} thankless and love me.
example.author: José María Lacalle García

meaning.exp: at the ending point of ... (even if not done)

example.lojban: .i {{co'u}} lo nu terxra kei ly ganse lo nu le mirli co'a jmive
example.english: {{As}} he {{finished}} painting, he felt that the deer came to life.
example.author: Demi

meaning.exp: ends when ...; until ...

example.lojban: .i sa'u ko troci {{co'u}} lo nu claxu lo titnanba
example.english: You just keep on trying {{till}} you run out of cake.
example.author: Jonathan Coulton

gloss: to express, to say — expression — audience — communication format

meaning.exp: x_1 (agent) expresses/says x_2 (sedu'u/text/lu'e concept) for audience x_3 via expressive medium x_4.

example.lojban: ni'o le ractu ku {{cusku}} lu xu do djica lo nu citka li'u
example.english: The rabbit {{said}}: "Did you want to eat?"
example.author: la lalxu

example.lojban: .i ka'e {{cusku}} zo co'o fi ro da
example.english: [We] can just {{say}} goodbye to everything.
example.author: Neru

example.lojban: .i my. {{cusku}} lo se du'u my. manci catlu po'o lo mi melbi lerfu
example.english: She (my mother) said she was just marvelling at my beautiful handwriting.

gloss: to want, to desire — (a) desire — purpose of desire

meaning.exp: x_1 desires/wants/wishes x_2 (event/state) for purpose x_3.

example.lojban: xu do {{djica}} lo nu citka
example.english: Did you {{want}} to eat?
example.author: la lalxu

example.lojban: .i ki'u bo mutce lo ka {{djica}} tu'a lo drani noltruti'u
example.english: Because he {{would have liked}} very much to have a real princess.
example.note: This sentence is an example of using {{tu'a}} for object of desire in x_2.
example.author: Hans Christian Andersen

gloss: to know (a fact) — knowledge — subject of knowledge — epistemology of knowledge

meaning.exp: x_1 knows fact(s) x_2 (du'u) about subject x_3 by epistemology x_4.

example.lojban: .i my ba zi {{djuno}} lo du'u do ti zvati
example.english: She will soon {{know}} that you are here.

example.lojban: ni'o pu ku ro prenu cu {{djuno}} fi lo makfa burcu po ko'a
example.english: Everyone {{knew}} about Liang's magic brush.
example.author: Demi

example.lojban: ku'i ma'a {{djuno}} so'i da lo jipci
example.english: But we {{have}} a lot of {{knowledge}} of chickens.
example.source: First dinosaurs may have been omnivores in the north hemisphere
example.author: Chelsea Whyte on NewScientist

example.lojban: .i {{le pu se djuno}} co'a fatci
example.english: {{The prophecy}} was fulfilled.
example.note: Prophecy = That which was known.
example.source: How the enemy came to Thlunrana
example.author: Lord Dunsany

example.lojban: .i da'i ma pu ve djuno
example.english: How should I know?
example.author: L. Frank Baum

gloss: correct, proper — aspect that x<sub>1</sub> is correct in — situation in which x<sub>1</sub> is correct  — standard of correctness

meaning.exp: x_1 is correct/proper/right/perfect in property/aspect x_2 (ka) in situation x_3 by standard x_4.
meaning.note: x<sub>1</sub> is normally not raised since the raised x<sub>1</sub> can just go to the x<sub>2</sub> place.

example.lojban: .i ro da poi lijda cu {{drani lo da se steci}}
example.english: Every religion {{is right in its specific way}}.
example.author: Andy Weir

example.lojban: la .alis. pu jinvi lo du'u ju'o ta {{drani lo ka tadji lo nu tavla lo smacu}}
example.english: Alice thought that must {{be the right way of speaking to a mouse}}.
example.author: Lewis Carroll

example.lojban: .i mi na ro roi {{drani lo ka djuno kei ja lo ka jinvi vau vau}} ta'o
example.english: I'm not always {{right in my knowledge or my opinion}}, by the way.
example.speaker: la ziren
example.note: This sentence is in JACU. To convert it to CLL Lojban, substitute {{ja}} with {{.a}}.

example.lojban: .i je mi na ralte le ci'artai {{poi drani fi zo'e}}
example.english: And I don't have the {{correct}} font {{for it}}.
example.speaker: yeet kitty

example.lojban: xu {{drani fo lo ka jbobau}}
example.english: Is it correct by Lojban standards?
example.speaker: dram
example.note: The type/usage of the "by standard" places are never specified or defined, rendering those places virtually useless. This sentence is a rare example of a "by standard" place being used.

gloss: different, other — what x<sub>1</sub> is different from

meaning.exp: x_1 isn't the-same-thing-as/is different-from/other-than x_2 by standard x_3; x_1 is something else.

example.lojban: .i zo ratcu 🐀 zo ractu 🐇 cu {{drata}} 😉
example.english: "ratcu" 🐀 and "ractu" 🐇 {{are different}} 😉
example.speaker: la janbe
example.note: The emoji and italics aren't standard parts of Lojban.

example.lojban: lo voksa nu cenba cu {{na drata}} lo se bilma be fi lo lenku
example.english: The change in his voice {{was no different from}} the sign of a cold.
example.author: Franz Kafka

example.lojban: .i {{no drata be lo troci}} ka'e ba snada prenu
example.english: {{Nobody other than those who try}} can be a successful person.
example.author: Djemynai

gloss: Connective: sumti afterthought and

meaning.exp: Logical connective: sumti afterthought and. Connects two sumti, such that the containing bridi is true if and only if it is true for each of the connected sumti.
meaning.note: Supplanted with {{je}} in JACU.

example.lojban: .i po'o do {{.e}} mi zvati
example.english: Just you {{and}} me [are here].
example.author: Andy Weir

example.lojban: .i .ei mi pajni ji'u lo se zukte {{.e nai}} lo valsi
example.english: I ought to have judged by deeds {{and not}} by words.
example.author: Antoine de Saint-Exupéry

meaning.exp: Letteral for e. When used alone, refers to the most recent sumti starting with {{e}}.

example.lojban: ni'o {{la .em.}} ca lo nu klama ti te zu'e lo nu bu'u xabju cu citno je melbi speni .i lo solri jo'u lo brife cu cnegau {{.e bu}} ji'a
example.english: When {{Aunt Em}} came there to live she was a young, pretty wife. The sun and wind had changed {{her}} (= Aunt Em), too.
example.author: L. Frank Baum

gloss: to translate, translator — to be translated, original text — target language — source language — (a work of) translation

meaning.exp: x_1 translates text/utterance x_2 to language x_3 from language x_4 with translation result x_5.

example.lojban: .i .e'u nai cai la nicte cadzu ba mulno spogau lo se terpa {{da poi fanva dei lo na logji bangu}}
example.english: WARNING! Night Walker will bring complete destruction by something scary to {{those who translate this into a non-logical language.}}
example.note: Those who are keen on quantification will notice that this sentence uses existential quantification on {{da poi ...}}, which means if there are multiple translators, only "at least one of them" will be destroyed, instead of "all" which is suggested by the content of the text. (Such interpretation would be accomplished with universal quantification {{ro da poi ...}}). Actually, the {{da}} is being used here as a generic pronoun, which is a common usage in texts from the 2000s.
example.author: Robin Lee Powell

example.lojban: .i mi na tcidu {{lo se fanva}} je cu mulno co kakne lo su'u jimpe fi {{lo xe fanva be fu do}}
example.english: I didn't read {{the original}}, and I can understand {{your translation}} completely.
example.note: This sentence is in JACU. To convert it to CLL Lojban, substitute {{je cu}} with {{gi'e}}.
example.speaker: la lunbe

example.lojban: ni'o xu ranji fa le nu na djuno lo du'u ma kau zabna lo ka ce'u zmiku {{lo nu fanva fi lo glibau fo la .lojban.}}
example.english: Are [you] still unsure what is preferable for automatically {{translating from Lojban to English}}?
example.note: The {{fo}} is not needed in this sentence.
example.speaker: la varik

gloss: Preposition: created by...

meaning.exp: Created by ...; Introduces an unnumbered sumti that plays the role of {{finti}}'s x<sub>1</sub> in the sentence.
meaning.note: The event described by the bridi is normally associated with the creation of something, and that the creator is the referent of the tagged sumti. Often seen in titles to indicate the author of a text.

example.lojban: ki'e {{jai fi'e}} mupli
example.english: Thanks, example-{{creator}}!
example.speaker: la fagri

example.lojban: clani kerlo {{fi'e}} la fagri
example.english: Long Ears, {{by}} Fagri
example.author: la fagri

example.lojban: .i mi jinvi lo du'u so'i cnino zmadu zgike {{be fi'e mi}} cu zabna
example.english: I think many newer songs {{by me}} are nice.
example.speaker: la janbe

example.lojban: .i gidva ro da fa lo se platu {{be fi'e mi}}
example.english: {{My}} plans were guiding everything.
example.author: JimmyThumbP

meaning.exp: Creating work ...; Introduces an unnumbered sumti that plays the role of {{finti}}'s x<sub>2</sub> in the sentence.
meaning.note: The event described by the bridi is associated with the creation of the referent of the tagged sumti. {{se fi'e}} is unattested.

meaning.exp: Creating with purpose ...; Introduces an unnumbered sumti that plays the role of {{finti}}'s x<sub>3</sub> in the sentence.
meaning.note: The event described by the bridi is associated with some event of creation, for a purpose indicated by the referent of the tagged sumti.

example.lojban: .i pacna {{te fi'e}} po'o lo nu kulgu'a snada
example.english: I {{invented}} [dreams] merely {{in hopes of}} completing [my] homework.
example.author: Last Note.

meaning.exp: Creating from ...; Introduces an unnumbered sumti that plays the role of {{finti}}'s x<sub>4</sub> in the sentence.
meaning.note: The event described by the bridi is associated with some event of creation, using pre-existing ideas or elements indicated by the referent of the tagged sumti.

example.lojban: lo du'u nandu fa lo nu cusku lu'e lo smuni poi simsa zo javni ku'o {{vefi'e}} lo drata smuni cu nibli pe'i lo du'u le javni smuni cu xamgu zmadu
example.english: The difficulty in expressing something similar to "javni" {{from}} other meanings means that the official meaning is better IMO.
example.speaker: _4Denthusiast

gloss: to create, to author — creation — purpose of creation — inspiration

meaning.exp: x_1 invents/creates/composes/authors x_2 for function/purpose x_3 from existing elements/ideas x_4.

example.lojban: .i mi {{finti}} le ti munje tu'a do po'o
example.english: I {{created}} this universe just for you.
example.author: Andy Weir

example.lojban: .i se ri'a bo mi {{finti fo ri}}
example.english: As a result, I {{created [them] based on it}}.
example.author: Worldbuilding Notes

gloss: to do, to bring about, (of a person, object) to cause — effect

meaning.exp: x_1 [person/agent] is an agentive cause of event x_2; x_1 does/brings about x_2.
meaning.note: Despite the "[person/agent]" in the definition, the x<sub>1</sub> needs not be volitional (which distinguishes it from {{zukte}}), nor does it need to be animate. The x<sub>1</sub> is normally not an event, as the case of x<sub>1</sub> being an event is covered by {{rinka}}.

example.lojban: .i .io la cevni zo'u doi lo zvati be vi ti ko {{gasnu}} lo nu sance fa lo gleki si'azgi
example.english: To God on high, all you in this place, {{let}} hymns ring out in joyful chorus!
example.author: Noise and Bells (la janbe)

example.lojban: .i mulgau lo co'a {{se gasnu}}
example.english: ..., [and] complete what [we have] started {{to do}}.
example.author: Djemynai

example.lojban: xu nai lo zekri {{poi .i'y gasnu ke'a}} cu cinri do
example.english: Doesn't the crime {{it ( = the word ie'o) caused}} interest you?
example.speaker: la lunbe
example.note: {{.i'y}} is a proposed cmavo equivalent to {{.i bu}}.

example.lojban: mi nelci lo'e gundi jibri .i ku'i ri {{tatpi gasnu}}
example.english: I like industrial jobs. But they {{are tiring}}.
example.note: This sentence showcase a common phenomenon of putting the effect in the seltau position of {{gasnu}}. In this sentence, {{tatpi gasnu}} is similar in meaning to {{gasnu lo nu tatpi}}. In such tanru formation, the x<sub>2</sub> of {{gasnu}} is usually left unfilled, and is assumed to be {{lo nu <seltau>}}.
example.speaker: qimar

gloss: Connective: forethought connective question

meaning.exp: Logical connective: all but tanru-internal forethought connective question. Asks the listener to supply a FLC that makes the containing statement true.
meaning.note: Supplanted with {{ga ji}} in JACU.

example.lojban: ni'o xu lo prenu co vajni cu {{ge'i}} ca ranji lo nu kansa ku {{gi}} ve'u sepli do gi'e pu co'a cliva fi lo drata se litru
example.english: As for the people important [to you], do they continue to accompany you{{? Or}} are they now distant and separated from you, having departed via their own paths{{?}}
example.author: doriko

gloss: happy, glad — source of happiness

meaning.exp: x_1 is happy/merry/glad/gleeful about x_2 (event/state).

example.lojban: .i lo xanka mutce rirni cu {{gleki}} lo nu lo verba za'o jmive
example.english: The very anxious parents are happy that the child is still alive.
example.author: la solpa'i

example.lojban: .i lo nu jelca cu crori'a ki'u lo nu mi tai {{gleki}} tu'a do
example.english: As they burned it hurt because I was so {{happy}} for you
example.author: Jonathan Coulton

gloss: to work on, worker — to be worked on, work — purpose, goal

meaning.exp: x_1 [person] labors/works on/at x_2 [activity] with goal/objective x_3.
meaning.note: Place structure parallels {{zukte}}.

example.lojban: .i mi {{gunka}} lo se junri cuntu
example.english: I {{am working on}} serious matters!
example.author: Antoine de Saint-Exupéry

example.lojban: .i la .gregor. cu so'i roi tirna lo nu ra nau zanru {{lo se gunka be lo mensi}}
example.english: Gregor would often hear them say how they appreciated {{the work his sister was doing}}.
example.author: Franz Kafka

example.lojban: .i la cmalu cu {{gunka}} fi tu'a lo cilylarcu
example.english: Tiny {{was working}} on her sewing.
example.note: This sentence can be understood as "Tiny was working, so her sewing [can look good]" (implicit parts in brackets), putting the {{tu'a lo cilylarcu}} in the x_3 place. If the {{tu'a lo cilylarcu}} were in the x_2 place the sentence would mean something like "Tiny was working on [finishing] her sewing".
example.author: la fagri

example.lojban: .i te zu'e lo nu snada {{lo mi te gunka}} kei no stuzi se mau ti maptiu
example.english: For achieving {{my goal}}, no places is better than here.
example.author: Ryūnosuke Akutagawa

gloss: Connective: sumti afterthought connective question

meaning.exp: Logical connective: sumti afterthought connective question. Connects two sumti and asks the listener to supply a sumti afterthought connective that makes the containing bridi true.

example.lojban: cacra li re vo pe'i {{ji}} li pa re pei
example.english: Twenty-four hours, I think; {{or}} is it twelve{{?}}
example.author: Lewis Carroll

meaning.exp: Connective: connective question. Connects two grammatical constructs of the same type and asks the listener to supply a connective that makes the containing bridi true.

example.lojban:
― coi jbope'o mi'e zi sipna
― puzi {{ji}} bazi
― naje li'abu'o u'i
example.english:
― Hello Lojban friends, I'm sleeping (from a short distance in time from now)
― To the past {{or}} to the future?
― The latter, should be obvious now, haha.
example.speaker: la srasu, la evis
example.note: The middle sentence would be {{puzi <u>je'i</u> bazi}} under CLL Lojban.

gloss: Discursive: additionally

meaning.exp: Discursive: indicate an additional case or additional cases.
meaning.note: Keywords include "also", "too", "additionally", "in addition", "as well", "moreover", "furthermore", "to boot", "even".

example.lojban: .i lo munje cu palci je'u .i {{ji'a}} lo nu jmive cu nibli lo nu cortu
example.english: The world is truly evil, {{and}} living implies suffering.
example.author: Fyren

gloss: to understand, to comprehend (a fact) — fact understood — subject of understanding

meaning.exp: x_1 understands/comprehends fact/truth x_2 (du'u) about subject x_3; x1 understands (fi) x3.

example.lojban: mi {{jimpe}} lo du'u do ma kau cinmo
example.english: I {{understand}} how you feel.
example.author: L. Frank Baum

example.lojban: .i .a bu snada lo ka {{jimpe}} tu'a lo valsi
example.english: She (Alice) made out the words.
example.note: Make out the words = Succeed to understand the words.
example.author: Lewis Carroll

example.lojban: .i {{jimpe}} fi lo selcni .i .au kelci ne'i le xamsi pe'a
example.english: {{Understanding}} emotions, I want to play in the (figurative) ocean.
example.author: LazuLight

example.lojban: .i do terpa lo nu mi jai gau xrani do se pi'o {{lo se jimpe be mi}}
example.english: You fear that I'll cause harm to you with {{my understandings}}.
example.author: Robin Lee Powell

gloss: to pay attention to, to mind, attentive — focus of attention

meaning.exp: x_1 is attentive towards/attends/tends/pays attention to object/affair x_2.

example.lojban: .i ko {{jundi}} le mi selsa'a
example.english: {{Pay attention}} to my song!
example.author: Kessoku Band

example.lojban: .i ca lo cabna cedra na prali fi lo nu {{na jundi}} tu'a lo bangu klesi
example.english: In the current times, there's no use in {{ignoring}} the dialects.
example.author: la uakci

gloss: to be able to — (of an event) possible, (an) ability — condition of possibility/ability

meaning.exp: x_1 is able to do/be/capable of doing/being x_2 (event/state) under conditions x_3 (event/state).

example.lojban: .i flegau fi lo kabri djacu lo kevna be lo kumfa .i lo tsiju cu {{kakne}} lo ka bloti kei lo ka go'i
example.english: Pour a cup of water into a depression in a room, then a seed can be a boat.
example.note: The first sentence is the condition of the second, as seen in the {{lo ka go'i}} as the second sentence's x_3.
example.author: Zhuangzi

example.lojban: ki'e .i mi {{kakne}} lo nu tcidu de'u kei lo nu na sidju
example.english: Thanks, I {{can}} read it without help.
example.speaker: la bakre'u

example.lojban: .i la'e di'u {{na se kakne}}
example.english: That's {{impossible}}.
example.author: Terry Bisson

example.lojban: .i xy. nurgau xy. {{ta'i lo se kakne}}
example.english: They reassure themselves {{as best they can}}.
example.author: Antoine de Saint-Exupéry

gloss: to cry, to weep — tear — reason of crying, to be cried about

meaning.exp: x_1 weeps/cries tears x_2 about/for reason x_3 (event/state).

example.lojban: .i se ki'u bo ro jabyboi cu binxo {{lo se klaku}}
example.english: And then the little bells are changed to {{tears}}.
example.author: Antoine de Saint-Exupéry

example.lojban: .i ko na {{klaku fi le marji}}
example.english: Don't {{cry for that material existence}}.
example.author: Noise and Bells (la janbe)

gloss: to go, to come — destination — origin, start — route — means of movement

meaning.exp: x_1 comes/goes to destination x_2 from origin x_3 via route x_4 using means/vehicle x_5.

example.lojban: mi {{klama}} .ii le tsani le mi munje be lo xrani
example.english: I'm scared, but I'm {{going}} to the sky away from my world full of trauma
example.author: Noise and Bells (la janbe)

example.lojban: .i le karce zo'a {{flecu klama}} fo le dargu pe le bartu noi ca'o manku binxo
example.english: Cars {{slushed}} by on the street outside, where it was getting dark.
example.author: Raymond Carver

example.lojban: .i mi {{klama fu}} le roldepre'e .a'o
example.english: I hope I can {{ride}} the local train still.
example.note: {{roldepre'e}} expands to {{ro denpa trene}}, Train that stops at every [station] = Local train.
example.author: inabakumori

example.lojban: .i ku'i mi se slabu lo go'i po'o {{ve klama}}
example.english: But I'm only familiar with said {{route}}.
example.author: la blutolpinxe

gloss: Article: the one(s) called...

meaning.exp: Name article. Converts a selbri, selecting its first argument, or any string of cmevla into a sumti.
meaning.note: The resulting expression refers specifically to an individual or individuals that the speaker has in mind and which the speaker names with the selbri or cmevla.

example.lojban: coi {{la na'e vajni ku}} noi je'a vajni
example.english: Hello {{Not Important}}, who is indeed important!
example.note: "Not Important" is the name of the person greeted. Note the {{ku}} in this expression: it closes the selbri name. if the {{ku}} wasn't there the name selbri becomes {{na'e vajni noi je'a vajni}}, in which the relative clause becomes part of the name.
example.speaker: Lucilla

example.lojban:
— .i ma jmina le jugbau jufra le kibypapri
— {{la .lukifer.kailus.delikatus.}} no'u {{la .yu'orb.}}
example.english:
— Who added the Chiese sentences to the webpage?
— {{Lucifer Caelius Delicatus}} a.k.a. {{Yuorb}}
example.note: Specifically chosen to showcase cmevla chaining, where multiple cmevla in a row functions as a single name. Also note the answer parses differently in regards to CBM: with CBM {{.lukifer.kailus.delikatus. no'u la .yu'orb.}} is a name; without CBM {{no'u la .yu'orb.}} is a relative phrase of {{la .lukifer.kailus.delikatus.}} signifying the equivalence between them. Also note {{yu'orb}} is not a standard Lojban cmevla because of the {{y}}.
example.speaker: la nalvai, la ilmen

meaning.context: when used with an inner quantifier
meaning.exp: The inner quantifier signifies the number of the referents the speaker has in mind. If no explicit inner quantifier is supplied, it defaults to {{su'o}}.
meaning.note: {{la}} is seldom used with quantifiers.

meaning.context: when used with an inner quantifier
meaning.exp: The inner quantifier is part of the name.
meaning.note: {{la}} is seldom used with quantifiers. The following example is the only instance of {{la}} with inner quantifier I found.

example.lojban: mi pu finti {{la ze tadji pe lu mi prami do li'u}} te zu'e lo nu loi se cinri cu kakne lo ka troci lo ka smucpa
example.english: I authored {{Seven Ways to Say "I Love You"}} so that those interested can try to get its meaning.
example.speaker: la solpa'i
example.note: "Seven Ways to Say 'I Love You'" probably refers to a set of seven sentences in Toaq. The quote is from June 2017, so the Toaq is supposedly not too distant from that.

gloss: Quotation: end ungrammatical/out-of-context/sentence fragment quotation

meaning.exp: End error quotation. Ends a questionable or out of context quotation. Never elidable.

example.lojban: .i lo'u lan lan la lan la la la la lan lan la lan la la la la lan lan la la lan la la la lan la la la la lan o'o'o'o'o'o'o'o'o'o lun lun lu lu'u'u'u'u'u lu lu lu lu lun lu lu lu lun lu {{le'u}}
example.author: Youmi Kimura

example.lojban: .i do lo'u .i lo mi panzi lo mi speni {{le'u}} .alcu do lo'u zo'u mo {{le'u}}
example.english: "My kids... my wife,{{"}} you said. "What about them?{{"}}
example.note: The entire sentence is grammatical, but becomes ungrammatical when split in half.
example.author: Andy Weir

gloss: Quotation: start ungrammatical/out-of-context/sentence fragment quotation

meaning.exp: Begin error quotation. Starts a questionable or out of context quotation. Text must be Lojban words, but needn't be grammatical. Terminate with {{le'u}}.

example.lojban: .i {{lo'u}} lan lan la lan la la la la lan lan la lan la la la la lan lan la la lan la la la lan la la la la lan o'o'o'o'o'o'o'o'o'o lun lun lu lu'u'u'u'u'u lu lu lu lu lun lu lu lu lun lu le'u
example.author: Youmi Kimura

example.lojban: .i do {{lo'u}} .i lo mi panzi lo mi speni le'u .alcu do {{lo'u}} zo'u mo le'u
example.english: {{"}}My kids... my wife," you said. {{"}}What about them?"
example.note: The entire sentence is grammatical, but becomes ungrammatical when split in half.
example.author: Andy Weir

gloss: beautiful, pretty — to find beautiful, to find pretty — beautiful aspect — beauty standard

meaning.exp: x_1 is beautiful/pleasant to x_2 in aspect x_3 (ka) by aesthetic standard x_4.

example.lojban:
— .i grusi blanu ca .i {{melbi}} mi .i xu lo do tsani cu {{melbi}} do
— .i {{melbi}} mi lo ka dilnu claxu blanu
example.english:
— It's grayish blue now. It's {{beautiful}} to me. Is your sky {{beautiful}} to you?
— It's {{beautiful}} to me in that it's blue without clouds.
example.speaker: la lunbe, niftg

example.lojban: .i pe'i ro bangu cu {{melbi fi da}}
example.english: I think every language {{is beautiful in some ways}}.
example.speaker: la xrula

example.lojban: .i ku'i mi {{se melbi}} le do ganto'a sai voksa
example.english: But I {{find}} your very deep voice {{beautiful}}.
example.speaker: la janbe

gloss: extreme, much, very — an extreme property

meaning.exp: x_1 is much/extreme in property x_2 (ka), towards x_3 extreme/direction; x_1 is, in x_2, very x_3.

example.lojban: ni'o le se morji be mi cu {{mutce}} le ka kalsa
example.english: My memories are {{very}} confused.
example.author: H. P. Lovecraft

example.lojban: .i cu'u so'e se slabu be mi mi {{mutce be fi tu'a lo mi se nanca be'o}} mencre
example.english: Most people who are familiar with me say I'm {{really}} smart {{for my age}}.
example.author: la blutolpinxe

example.lojban: .i ja'e bo ca ku mi {{cinmo lo mutce}} gi'e kakne co zukte no da
example.english: As a result I {{am overwhelmed}} and cannot do anything now.
example.speaker: la nalvai
example.note: To be overwhelmed = To feel an extreme emotion

gloss: to like, fond — to be liked

meaning.exp: x_1 is fond of/likes/has a taste for x_2 (object/state).

example.lojban: .i mi {{nelci}} ro selci be do
example.english: I {{like}} every one of your cells.
example.author: Djemynai

example.lojban: .i mi {{nelci}} ca lo nicte lo nu tirna lo tarci
example.english: At night I {{love to}} listen to the stars.
example.author: Antoine de Saint-Exupéry

example.lojban: ko te cmene fi {{lo do se nelci}}
example.english: Call it {{whatever you like}}.
example.author: Lewis Carroll

gloss: to use, to employ — to be used, tool — function, purpose

meaning.exp: x_1 uses/employs x_2 [tool, apparatus, machine, agent, acting entity, material] for purpose x_3.

example.lojban: ro'e pe'i va {{pilno}} lo dikca lo nu jukpa
example.english: Aha, they must {{use}} electricity to cook there.
example.author: Kenji Miyazawa

example.lojban: .i mu'i ku so'i da {{pilno}} lo laldo ve cilre lo ka cilre fi lo catni lojbo
example.english: Because of it, many {{used}} old textbooks to learn the official Lojban.
example.author: la uakci

example.lojban: .i ma ca sevzi {{te pilno}} le bangu
example.english: What is the current identity {{function}} of the language?
example.author: M. Paul Lewis and Gary F. Simons

gloss: Relative phrase marker: is specific to ...

meaning.exp: Restrictive relative phrase marker: which is specific to ...; normal possessive physical/legal.

example.lojban: ni'o pu ku ro prenu cu djuno fi lo makfa burcu {{po}} ko'a
example.english: Everyone knew about Liang{{'s}} magic brush.
example.author: Demi

meaning.exp: Equivalent to {{lo su'u}}. Terminate with {{nei}} or {{tei}}.

example.lojban: .i mi djuno {{po}} zanfu'a ri
example.english: I know {{[how]}} lucky they are.
example.author: Mèremim

gloss: people, person

meaning.exp: x_1 is a person/people (noun) [not necessarily human]; x_1 displays personality/a persona.

example.lojban: .i ro {{prenu}} cu mrobi'o
example.english: Every {{person}} dies.
example.author: Andy Weir

gloss: similar, to be similar to ... — what x<sub>1</sub> is similar to — similarity, commonality

meaning.exp: x_1 is similar/parallel to x_2 in property/quantity x_3 (ka/ni); x_1 looks/appears like x_2.

example.lojban: .i xu ko'a {{simsa}} lo .orfolei lo ka tabyselcmu pensi gi'e farvi fo lo rectu
example.english: Are they {{like}} the orfolei? [You know,] a carbon-based intelligence that goes through a meat stage?
example.author: Terry Bisson

example.lojban: .i mu'i bo ca da do binxo {{lo simsa be mi}}
example.english: Because one day, you'll become {{like me}}.
example.author: Andy Weir

gloss: to sleep, asleep

meaning.exp: x_1 is asleep (adjective); x_1 sleeps/is sleeping.

example.lojban: .i mi vlalinkei ca lo nu mi {{sipna}}
example.english: I play vlalinkei while I{{'m asleep}}.
example.author: la solpa'i

gloss: to be colored, to have color — color, hue — to preceive color

meaning.exp: x_1 is/appears to be of color/hue x_2 as perceived/seen by x_3 under conditions x_4.

example.lojban: lo fagri cu na {{skari lo drani}}
example.english: The fire is not {{of the right color}}.
example.author: Robin Lee Powell

example.lojban: .i ju'o .ia ro prenu cu {{skari}} so'i melbi joi so'i fegli
example.english: I'm sure everyone's {{painted in colors}}, many beautiful and many ugly.
example.author: H△G

gloss: meaning, interpretation — (of an expression, of an event...) to mean, to be taken as ... — to interpret

meaning.exp: x_1 is a meaning/interpretation of x_2 recognized/seen/accepted by x_3.
meaning.note: x<sub>1</sub> is normally an abstraction (most commonly a {{du'u}}); x<sub>2</sub> takes a wide range of types, with texts, desctiption, abstractions all being attested.

example.lojban: .i di'u zo'u ma {{smuni}} zo ta
example.english: What's {{the meaning of}} {ta} in the last sentence?
example.speaker: la nalvai

example.lojban: .i ru'a lo'u do cinmo ma doi ro do le'u {{se djica jai smuni}}
example.english: I assume "do cinmo ma doi ro do" {{is what [you] want it to mean}}.
example.speaker: la janbe
example.note: The {{jai}} raises the quote, {{lo'u do cinmo ma doi ro do le'u}}, into an abstraction so it can go into the x<sub>1</sub> place.

example.lojban: .i lo du'u da de natfe cu {{se smuni}} lo du'u da .o nai de ka'e jetnu
example.english: "A contradicts B" {{means}} only one of A and B can be true.
example.note: This sentence is localized from the original text, so it doesn't match literally to the original. The {{da}} and {{de}} are being used as generic pronouns, which is a common usage in texts from the 2000s.
example.author: Lewis Carroll

example.lojban: .i la'e di'u cu {{se smuni}} lo barda mukti la .gregor.
example.english: It {{is taken as}} a great motivation by Gregor.
example.author: Franz Kafka

example.lojban: .i krinu lo nu mabla ja dukse {{te smuni}} noi je'u fasnu ma'i lo ma'a cecmu
example.english: This can lead to mis{{interpretation}} and/or over{{interpretation}} — and that is what happens in our community.
example.author: la uakci

gloss: to tell, to talk to — to be talked to — subject of talk — language used

meaning.exp: x_1 talks/speaks to x_2 about subject x_3 in language x_4.

example.lojban: .i la .cíluuax. .ainmo lo ka {{tavla}} la cmalu le nu cy. fliba
example.english: Sheelua intended to {{talk}} to Tiny about her (= Tiny's) failures.
example.author: la fagri

example.lojban: ni'o la .stefen. co'a sanga gi'e {{tavla}} fi lo nu litru vau la .gliban.
example.english: Stefen started to sing and {{talked}} about the journey in English.
example.author: Robin Lee Powell

gloss: Text Structure: Open parenthesis

meaning.exp: Opens a parenthetical note. The text inside must be grammatical Lojban. Terminate with {{toi}}.
meaning.note: The text inside contains additional information that isn't essential to the meaning of the sentence, but can still help.

example.lojban: .i mi djuno ri'a lo su'u mi cmima le jatna kamni pe la logbau skejgu {{to la'o gy ~ The Loglan Institute ~ gy toi}}
example.english: I know, because I'm a member of the leader comitee associated with the science institute of Loglan {{([English] ~ The Loglan Institute ~)}}
example.speaker: la janbe

example.lojban: le mi bruna {{to se rirni le se rirni pe le mamta pe le mi mamta toi}} cu bilma
example.english: My brother, {{(my mother's mother's child's child)}} is ill.
example.speaker: la kanis
example.note: Note that the {{toi}} in this sentence is elidable, as the content in the parentheses cannot take the second selbri introduced by {{cu}}.

example.lojban: .i da'i {{to se va'u lo nu darlu toi}} lo jmive je pensi cu kakne lo nu zasti ze'o lo bitmu be lo botpi
example.english: ..., granting {{(for the sake of argument)}} that life and thought exist beyond the walls of the caraffe.
example.note: If the {{toi}} was elided in this sentence, the parentheses will automatically close just before the {{cu}}, for the same reason as in the previous example.
example.author: Robert Louis Stevenson

gloss: word, (of a word) to mean — meaning (of a word) — (of a language) to have a word for...

meaning.exp: x_1 is a word meaning/causing x_2 in language x_3; (adjective: x_1 is lexical/verbal).

example.lojban: .i ma {{valsi}} zo xa'o le do pambau
example.english: What {{is the word for}} "too soon" in the language of your love?
example.author: Noise and Bells (la janbe)

example.lojban: .i ku'i pau le'o sai zo makcu ma cu {{valsi}}
example.english: But what the hell does "adult" {{mean}} to begin with?
example.author: Neru

gloss: beneficial, good — to benefit

meaning.exp: x_1 (object/event) is good/beneficial/nice/[acceptable] for x_2 by standard x_3.

example.lojban: .i zu'u nai lo nu rapsku cu {{xamgu}} .a bu lo nu cilre
example.english: On the other hand, repeating {{is good}} for her (= Alice's) learning.
example.author: Lewis Carroll

example.lojban: {{xamgu fi}} lo nu drani lo ka lo slaka cu rilti
example.english: It's {{good in the sense that}} it scans properly.
example.note: "scans properly" = "correct in that the syllables makes a rhythm".
example.speaker: Magnap

example.lojban: .i je ku'i ri {{se xamgu}} ju'o lo nu lo plini cu glare zenba
example.english: But it certainly {{benefits from}} the planet warming.
example.author: Ryan Cross on Science

gloss: to observe, observer — to be observered — means of observation

meaning.exp: x_1 observes/[notices]/watches/beholds x_2 using senses/means x_3 under conditions x_4.
meaning.note: Attested usage of this word displays family resemblance, ranging from "to watch" to "to behold" to "to feel" to "to notice". Community usage usually aligns with the English usage of "watch" (e.g. {{zgana lo skina}} is common but {{zgana lo pixra}} is rare). I didn't find usage of the x<sub>3</sub> and x<sub>4</sub> places.

example.lojban: .i ko'e {{zgana}} le nu le cifnu cu cliva vo'a
example.english: She {{felt}} the baby going from her.
example.author: Raymond Carver

example.lojban: .i do ba {{zgana}} lo nu mi ja'a sai te tinbe
example.english: You will {{see}} I am indeed obeyed!
example.author: Antoine de Saint-Exupéry

example.lojban: ca lo jibni lo lojbo ku se xlali lo {{frili se zgana}} poi pagbu lo vanbi be lo bangu
example.english: Recently, Lojbanists are suffering from the {{easily-noticed}} part of the environment of the language.
example.author: la uakci

example.lojban: ca ku zo'u mi {{zgana}} co skina la andor
example.english: For now I'm {{watching}} the video [series] "Andor".
example.speaker: qimar

gloss: to be (present) at — place, location

meaning.exp: x_1 (object/event) is at/attending/present at x_2 (event/location).

example.lojban: lo finpe cu {{zvati}} ma
example.english: Where {{are}} the fish?
example.author: Demi

example.lojban: .i ca facki lo du'u pa ractu ku {{co'a zvati}} le kumfa
example.english: And now, they discovered that a rabbit {{had entered}} the room.
example.author: la lalxu

example.lojban: .i lo cmalu noltru noi {{zvati lo nu zvagau lo barda balji}} cu birti lo du'u ba barkla by fa lo se manci tolcanci
example.english: The little prince, who {{was present at the appearance of a huge bud}}, was sure that some sort of miraculous apparition must emerge from it.
example.author: Antoine de Saint-Exupéry

example.lojban: .i {{lo se zvati be mi}} cu tolmanku ze'i lo snidu
example.english: {{The place where I am}} lit up for a second.
example.author: Djemynai
